issues.description: The problem statement (UML and descriptive text) specifies acceptSupplyDelivery should take four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) — i.e., acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int). The provided solution implements acceptSupplyDelivery with only three parameters (ingredient name, price, quantity) — acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int). This is a signature mismatch that will confuse students about the expected method parameters and prevents a direct implementation matching the UML/specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the acceptSupplyDelivery signature consistent across artifacts. Either: (A) Update the problem statement (UML and descriptive text) to specify acceptSupplyDelivery(String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) (remove the supplier name parameter), or (B) change the implementation signature to acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) and (if supplierName is not needed) ignore or log it. Choose one approach and apply it to both the specification and the implementation so students are not confused about the required parameters.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) specifies acceptSupplyDelivery with four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) — signature: acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int). The solution implementation defines acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity) with only three parameters (missing the supplier parameter) and a different parameter ordering. This API mismatch between the described requirement and the provided implementation will confuse students: they may implement the method with the supplier parameter as required by the exercise, but the reference code uses a different signature, preventing a clear one-to-one mapping of the requirement to the implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution implementation with the problem specification by changing the method signature to include the supplier parameter: public static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) { ... } (supplierName can be unused if not needed). Alternatively, update the problem statement/UML to specify the three-parameter signature used in the solution if the supplier is intentionally not required.
